Fig. 1 Schematic representation of the OER mechanism in acidic (indicated by black arrow) and alkaline (indicated by red arrow) environments. Fig 1 Fig. 2 (a) Schematic diagram of solvothermal synthesis; (b) Magnetron sputtering synthesis diagram; (c) Schematic diagram of electrodeposition synthesis. Fig 2 Fig. 3 (a) Synthesis steps of HEAs (FeCoNiIrRu); (b) TEM images of HEAs (FeCoNiIrRu); (c and d) Corresponding free energy maps of OER by AEM on five metal sites on the surface of FeCoNiIrRu at U = 0 V and U = 1.23 V; (e) Upper temperature distribution on the multicarbon nanotube during irradiation; (f) SEM images of HEAs (FeCoNiCuPtIr); (g): OER free energy maps of one and five hollow sites for OH adsorption; (h) STEM images of HEAs (AlNiCoIrMo) after de-alloying; (i) Comparison of Ir mass activity at 1.5 V with literature data. Fig 3 Fig. 4 (a) XRD image of HEAs (FeCoNiCuMn-NPs); (b) SEM image of HEAs (FeCoNiCuMn-NPs); (c) OER performance map of HEAs (FeCoNiCuMn-NPs); (d) Flow chart of HE-MOF for the in-situ growth of HEAs (NiCoFeZnMo) on nickel foam; (e) SEM image of HEAs (NiCoFeZnMo); (f) TEM image of HEAs (NiCoFeZnMo); (g) HRTEM image of HEAs (NiCoFeZnMo); (h) Atomic force microscopy (AFM) image. Fig 4 Fig. 5 (a) SEM image of HEAs (NiFeCuCoW); (b) SEM image of HEAs (NiFeCuCoW) after work; (c) SEM image of HEAs (FeCoNiCrMn); (d) SEM image of HEAs (NiCoFeZnMo) after work; (e) SEM image of HEAs (NP-NiCuMnCoFe); (f) Density of states of the various elements in the center of the d-band; (g) Mechanism of the OER on the Fe site; and (h) Gibbs free-energy diagrams of the various oxygen species in the OER process. High entropy alloys (HEAs) are composed of five or more atomic components, forming a homogeneous solid solution with a highly disordered crystal structure. This unique structure can increase the number and diversity of surface active sites, which is conducive to improving the rate and selectivity of catalytic reactions. Additionally, it exhibits good catalytic activity, stability, and antioxidant properties. This paper detailedly discusses the preparation method, structural characteristics, and application in catalysis of HEAs catalysts for oxygen evolution reaction (OER). Different methods can control the composition and microstructure of the alloy, thereby affecting the catalytic performance. Through density functional theory (DFT) studies on HEAs, it is demonstrated that Gibbs free energy is reduced, further confirming the effect of HEAs on OER performance. The various techniques for preparing HEAs and their derivatives, as well as the incorporation of different elements, are summarized. These different methods and introductions can synthesize diverse catalyst structures with evaluated electrocatalytic performances. HEAs catalysts can utilize waste metals or recycled materials along with green synthesis methods, making them promising in terms of sustainability and environmental protection to promote sustainable development and application of catalytic technology. Graphical abstract The traditional four-electron transfer process of OER necessitates a large overpotential. However, the unique properties of high-entropy alloys can alleviate this issue, thereby creating new opportunities for OER. The catalyst required can be synthesized in various environments, and its uniform composition can expose more active sites and enhance catalytic activity. The complex crystal structure formed by the diverse elements also grants it excellent corrosion resistance. Furthermore, high entropy alloys exhibit outstanding electrochemical performance and cycle stability, thus enhancing the efficiency and reliability of the entire fuel cell system. Image, graphical abstract Keywords HEAs Electro-catalysis DFT Preparation method OER Data availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction The emergence of problems such as energy crisis and environmental pollution [1,2] has forced mankind to study sustainable green energy. Hydrogen has been used as a clean energy source [3], and the decomposition reaction of water can produce hydrogen (H2) and oxygen (O2), electrochemical water decomposition is divided into two half-reactions, which are the OER at the anode and the hydrogen evolution reaction (HER) at the cathode [4], but the OER is the traditional 4e- transfer process [5], which greatly reduces the energy conversion efficiency, making the overall water decomposition efficiency limited [6]. The noble metals Ru and Ir are highly active as raw materials for oxygen precipitation reaction catalysts [7–9], but their application prospects are hindered by disadvantages such as high cost and low reserves. Pt as a raw material for catalysts in HER also exhibits high activity, but also hinders its development caused by its rarity and large cost [10]. Therefore, researchers are committed to study low-cost and high-activity electrochemical catalysts. Due to their high catalytic activity, cost-effectiveness, and abundant reserves, transition metals have demonstrated promising potential as the raw materials of electrocatalyst [11,12], Nevertheless, the stability performance of transition metals remains unsatisfactory and requires urgent resolution. It is found that polymetal can change the disadvantage of traditional electrocatalysts, and further improve the activity and stability of catalysts. Hydrothermal synthesis of binary NiFe alloy nanoparticle electrocatalysts has been documented in the literature, where mesoporous and macroporous structures are formed at 30–150 nm on the catalyst surface, providing shorter diffusion paths, increasing the number of active sites, and thus exhibiting excellent OER performance and durability [13]. FeCoNi ternary alloy film on nickel foam has been prepared by aerosol assisted chemical vapor deposition technology. The film shows a three-dimensional flower shape, which can magnify the specific surface area, increase the number of active sites, and thus improve the charge transfer rate [14]. By using the unique configuration entropy phase stabilization mechanism of medium-entropy oxides, the structural stability of single-phase solid oxides is significantly enhanced by ingeniously introducing four metal cations into them. Furthermore, researchers have successfully synthesized metal oxide core-shell materials with nanoporous structures, which not only integrates abundant Cu elements, but also cleverly generates the oxygen vacancies, and the synergistic effect between the two phases greatly promotes the transport efficiency of electrons and ions, thereby significantly improving the conductivity of the materials [15]. In order to further improve the OER performance of the material, the researchers further study the multi-alloy electrocatalyst, and ultimately find the HEAs. HEAs are newly developed electrocatalytic materials with high entropy values, which are alloys consisting of five and more metals uniformly in molar ratios [16,17]. Due to their excellent electrocatalytic activity, stability, and superconductivity, HEAs are regarded as highly promising for applications [18–20]. HEAs have some unique effects, which are categorized into the following four points in total, high-entropy effect, lattice distortion effect, slow diffusion effect, and "cocktail effect" [21–23]. High entropy effect is defined from the perspective of entropy, which is an effect mainly caused by too many types of elements, which can make the increase of entropy value of the whole system chaos [24]. Lattice distortion is due to atomic size mismatch deviating from the ideal position [25], the influence of atoms and the environment around atoms makes the distortion more serious [26] and the position of the atoms is not fixed to the extent that the enthalpy of the alloy is higher [27]. Crystal lattice distortion can serve as the atomic interfaces, accelerating electron transfer, mitigating the binding energy of chemical reactants, and even enhancing catalytic activity [28,29]. The slow diffusion effect means that the atoms diffuse more slowly, with fewer atomic diffusion channels, lower diffusion coefficients, and higher required activation energies [30]. The "cocktail effect" is a synergistic effect between different atoms, which increases the properties of alloys, such as mechanical properties, stability, and corrosion resistance, by adding different elements [31,32]. Compared with the traditional electrochemical catalysts, there are more kinds of elements in HEAs, and the electronic structure and catalytic performance can be better regulated by introducing different elements [33], different elements can show their own strengths, improving the performance of electrocatalysts. After forming a solid solution, HEAs typically exhibit simple phase structures and display typical crystal structures, including face-centered cubic (FCC) [34], body-centered cubic (BCC), and hexagonal close-packed structures. Additionally, it is possible for them to form amorphous phases [35,36]. The composition of various metal elements of HEAs can promote the formation of various catalytic active sites, thus enhacning the reaction rate and efficiency of OER. Moreover, the multi-element composition can improve the stability of the catalyst in the electrochemical reaction and reduce the degradation in the long-term reaction process. This stability is particularly important for OER, as the reaction often leads to corrosion and deactivation of the catalyst. By selecting suitable metal elements, the conductivity of HEAs can be optimized, making the electron conduction during the reaction more efficient, which is essential to improve the overall reaction efficiency of OER. The development of HEAs helps to find the alternatives with more environmentally and friendly abilities to the traditional precious metal catalysts, such as platinum, which not only reduces the cost of the catalyst, but also decreases the reliance on scarce resources [37]. The excellent properties of HEAs have a very good application prospect in the future development, and HEAs are divided into many types, such as high entropy precious metals, high entropy transition metals, refractory HEAs, etc. [38], there are also some high-entropy derivatives, such as high-entropy hydroxides, oxides, sulfides, phosphide and so on. The properties of the catalyst have been summarized by introducing different elements and different synthesis methods. 2 OER mechanism The two most widely accepted OER mechanisms include the traditional adsorption product evolution mechanism (AEM) and the lattice oxygen mechanism (LOM) [39,40]. These two mechanisms play an important role in explaining the OER. In the AEM mechanism, oxygen molecules are firstly adsorbed on the surface of the catalyst. The adsorbed oxygen atoms are then released to the gas phase through a series of surface reactions, such as OO combining to form O2 gas. The key to this mechanism is the active site on the catalyst surface and its interaction with oxygen. The LOM mechanism involves the participation of lattice oxygen atoms in the catalyst material. Lattice oxygen atoms are part of the crystal structure of the catalyst material, being released from the lattice during oxygen evolution, and then releases into gaseous oxygen through surface reactions. This mechanism emphasizes the migration and release of oxygen within the catalyst. During LOM electrolysis, the electric potential on the anode electrode oxidizes oxygen atoms or oxygen ions on the catalyst surface, thereby releasing electrons. These electrons flow into the external circuit, creating an electric current. The lattice oxygen in the catalyst is released through an oxidation reaction, and the lattice oxygen ions (O2-) are desorbed from the catalyst surface to form oxygen atoms (O), a process that is often a key step in the formation of O2. The desorbed O is further oxidized to O2, which combines with other oxygen atoms to form O2 and is eventually released into the gas phase [41]. The process of forming O2 from desorption O requires the participation of electrons. These electrons flow through the electrode to the external circuit to complete the current transmission of the electrochemical reaction. After desorption, oxygen deficiency may occur on the surface of catalyst. The catalyst needs to regenerate these oxygen sites by reacting with O2 in the environment to restore catalytic activity. The OO combination step in LOM is very easy [42], which is usually the rate-determining step in AEM, so LOM has an advantage in terms of current density. OER is a chemical reaction that involves the electron transfer of oxygen molecules. There are three intermediates (O*, OH* and OOH*) involved in this process [43]. The reaction mechanism includes the required conditions, especially the pH value of the solution [44]. The following equation shows the OER reaction mechanism and diagram in the different environments (Fig. 1 ). In the above formula, * represents the catalyst surface active site [45]. This process requires four consecutive electron transfer steps, as well as the involvement of three different intermediates, allowing oxygen molecules to be activated and broken down into oxygen atoms. The slow kinetic performance of OER in alkaline media is due to the limitation caused by the multi-step process of proton transfer. In acidic conditions, the sluggishness of OER is attributed to the four-electron/four-proton coupling step and the formation of OO bonds [46]. As the material with a new type, HEAs can synthesize a variety of metals to prepare catalysts. HEAs has high strength [47], corrosion resistance [48], high ductility and fracture toughness [49]. The four properties of HEAs can be used to play a better role in OER. The classification and preparation of HEAs are described in the next chapter. 3 Preparation of HEAs and high entropy derivatives 3.1 Preparation method of HEAs The methods of preparation and evaluation of the properties of HEAs and high entropy derivatives will be presented, which are prepared by a large number of methods, such as solvothermal methods [50], magnetron sputtering [51], electrodeposition [52], and so on. The solvothermal method is typically conducted under high temperature and pressure conditions, facilitating the dissolution and diffusion of reactants to enhance the uniformity and purity of the catalysts [53]. The particle size and morphology of catalyst can be controlled by adjusting the reaction conditions, which is helpful to obtain the uniform distribution of catalyst components and improve catalytic activity. The properties of the catalyst can be adjusted by selecting suitable solvents and additives. Magnetron sputtering uses the target material as the target source. The target material is placed in a vacuum chamber. The inert gas is passed into the vacuum chamber, and by applying high voltage, the gas is ionized to form plasma. Magnetic fields are applied to control the movement of electrons in the plasma, increasing the probability of ions colliding with the target. The magnetic field makes the ions move along the spiral trajectory on the surface of the target, which can improve the sputtering efficiency. High-energy ions strike the surface of the target, making the target atoms or molecules to be knocked out. These sputtered atoms or molecules will be deposited on the surface of the substrate, to form a film. The properties and thickness of the film can be controlled by adjusting the sputtering conditions. The magnetron sputtering method can accurately control the structure of thin films, including crystal structure, grain size and orientation. This controllability can optimize the surface properties of the catalyst and improve its activity and selectivity. In the electrodeposition process, it is firstly necessary to prepare the electrolyte containing the catalyst precursor. The electrolyte usually contains a precursor of the target catalyst, such as a solution of metal ions. Two electrodes are arranged in the electrolytic cell: the working electrode and the reference electrode. The substrate is usually the object that needs to be coated with the catalyst, and the reference electrode is used to measure the potential. An electric current or voltage is applied to reduce and deposit metal ions in the electrolyte onto the substrate surface. The reduction reaction usually occurs at the working electrode, where metal ions are reduced from the electrolyte to metal and form a thin film. As the current continues, metal ions are gradually deposited on the surface of the substrate to form a catalyst film. The deposition rate can be controlled by adjusting the current density and electrolyte composition. By changing the current density, deposition time, temperature and other parameters, the thickness, morphology and properties of the catalyst can be controlled to meet the needs of different catalytic applications. Sometimes post-treatment steps, such as annealing, cleaning, etc. can be used to improve the performance and stability of the catalyst. By selecting different electrolytes and electrode materials, electrodeposition can achieve precise control of the structure and composition of the catalyst. This flexibility makes it possible to prepare catalysts with specific structures and compositions to meet the requirements of different reactions. Both theoretical research and practical application of HEAs show very excellent performance. The obtained samples are characterized by different methods, and the electrochemical data are evaluated and summarized. Different methods and the introduction of different elements to synthesize HEAs are summarized, and it is concluded that there is a better development in the application of electrolytic water (Fig. 2 ). 3.2 Preparation of high-entropy catalyst 3.2.1 Precious metals HEAs Among the noble metal catalysts, ruthenium (RuO2) oxide [54] and iridium (IrO2) oxide [55] are the best OER catalysts in the present time [56], so the synthesis of HEAs electrocatalysts was carried out by adding noble metals to improve the performance of the catalysts. The in situ synthesis of HEAs (FeCoNiIrRu) nanoparticles in carbon nanofibers have been synthesized using electrostatic spinning [57], and nanofiber membranes are obtained from a solution of HEAs (FeCoNiIrRu) precursor. Finally, the catalysts are successfully synthesized by graphitization, as shown in Fig. 3 a. A series of tests are carried out in an acidic environment, as observed by transmission electron microscope (TEM) (Fig. 3b), the crystal plane spacing is about 2.1 Å corresponding to the FCC structure. The free energy diagram corresponding to the OER of five metals by AEM reveals that when U is 0 V and 1.23 V (Fig. 3c and 3d), the OER free energy of the Ir site is determined to be 1.67 V, establishing Ir as the most active site in the HEA (FeCoNiRuIr) catalyst. The transition metals in this catalyst have low electronegativity, and the role of noble metals (Ir, Ru) in it can redistribute the overall electronegativity to improve the activity of OER and HER, and thus increase the precipitation of O2 and H2. Using the slow diffusion effect in HEAs can make the leaching and dissolution of metals in the catalyst more slowly, obtaining the excellent durability. HEAs (FeCoNiCuPtIr) nanocatalysts are synthesized by rapid laser shock [58], making the nanoparticles smaller and more evenly distributed on multi-walled carbon nanotubes (MWCNT) can increase the number of exposed active sites. The upper temperature distribution on the multi-walled carbon nanotubes is observed at 50 ms irradiation (Fig. 3e). During the measurement, the temperature reached nearly 1600 K in a very short time, and the cooling rate is also extremely fast. This extremely fast rising and cooling rate facilitates the decomposition of salt precursors to form solid-soluble HEAs. From the scanning electron microscope (SEM) in Fig. 3f, it can be seen that the nanoparticles are very evenly distributed on the surface of the multi-carbon nanotubes. The rapid impact method can synthesize a smaller nanoparticle and prevent the Austenite ripening effect from occurring, thereby preventing the nanoparticle size from growing larger. The electrochemical performance test results in alkaline environment show that the double layer capacitance reaches 152.7 mF·cm-2 and the initial potential is only 1.46 mV, and the DFT calculations indicate that the whole OER reaction paths of hollow sites (Ni-Ni-Cu) and (Ir-Co-Co) as shown in Fig. 3g. Moreover, the hollow sites Ir-Co-Co have a smaller OER reaction path than that of the hollow sites Ni-Ni-Cu. Cu has smaller O2 desorption energy and better OER catalytic activity, and the introduction of Ir atoms indeedly enhances the adsorption and desorption of oxygen and hydrogen, which also enables to reduce the coupling of adsorbates to the alloy surface, thus obtaining an extension lifetime of the catalyst. Synthesis of Nano-porous HEAs (NP-HEAs) by the Dealloying Method [59], this HEAs (AlNiCoIrMo) removes most of the Al element during the synthesis process., so that the formation of nanoscale pores and alloying ligaments, which can wholly increase the activity of the catalyst. after dealloying in Fig. 3h, scanning transmission electron microscopy (STEM) images confirmes the mesoporous and nano-ligaments of the catalyst, and electrochemical tests show that the initial potential of NP-AlNiCoIrMo is 1.42 V, which is lower than that of IrO2 (1.48 V). The reason for the higher catalytic activity of NP-AlNiCoIrMo than IrO2 is related to the increased covalency of Ir-O bond, and the lower loading capacity of Ir, which indicates the better application prospect. When electrochemical tests are carried out in acidic solutions, it can be found that the overpotentials are only 233 mV and 255 mV at current densities of 10 and 20 mA·cm-2, which indicates that the electrochemical performances are significantly better than those for IrO2. The OER activity is stronger due to the reduced Ir content. In addition, the addition of Mo and Co could reduce the loading, and the NP-AlNiCoIrMo could provide≈115 mA·mg-1 of high quality current density (Fig. 3i) is the fact. The synthesis of HEAs has supplied another improvement in the activity and stability of the electrocatalysts and further progress in the direction of electrocatalytic research. Noble metals (Ru, Ir, Pt, etc.) usually have good catalytic activity, which can promote water decomposition catalytic reactions. Their high catalytic activity may allow HEAs catalysts to excel in some reactions. Precious metals usually provide high selectivity and help direct the generation of specific products, which is particularly important for some complex catalytic reactions. Precious metals have high corrosion resistance, which makes them to maintain their catalytic performance under some extreme conditions, such as high temperatures and acidic or alkaline environments. When precious metals are combined with other metallic elements in HEAs, synergistic effects may promote the catalysts to outperform the sum of the properties of the single metals or alloys. This may include effects such as increased catalytic activity, selectivity or stability. Having excelled in electrochemical catalysis, it is possible that in HEAs the electrochemical properties of the whole alloy may be affected by adjusting the electronic structure, contributing to certain electrochemical catalytic applications. Precious metal catalysts have a long lifetime, making them more viable for industrial applications. The selection of elements for the synthesis of catalysts with excellent performance is extremely important, and the physical and chemical properties of the elements need to be utilized for selection. In the synthesis of HEAs with different structures, it is necessary to be clear about the properties of the elements, for example, the use of de-alloying method requires the selection of elements to ensure the formation of pores and the stabilization of the structure, and to increase the activity while ensuring a better stability. The catalysts synthesized in the above mentioned experiments are of nanoscale, and the synthesis of nanoscale alloys is generally done using magnetron sputtering [60,61], electrostatic spinning [62], and pulsed laser deposition techniques [63], etc., by using different methods to synthesize the desired nanoparticle sizes [64], as well as the structure of the catalysts required. However, the synthesis of HEAs at the nanoscale is very demanding on the material, and the structure of the catalyst should be stable after the formation of the nanoscale without collapsing, and the adsorption of impurities on the surface of the catalyst should also be prevented to ensure that the service life of the catalyst and the catalytic activity remain unchanged. The HEAs in the above materials still have the presence of precious metals, low reserves and high costs, so they are limited in large-scale put into use, hindering their further development. 3.2.2 Pure transition-metal HEAs In the previous section, the precious metals ruthenium (Ru) and iridium (Ir) are mentioned as part of the raw materials for synthesizing HEAs. Although the ratio of the precious metals ruthenium (Ru) and iridium (Ir) in synthesizing catalysts has been reduced, the cost of the precious metals as raw materials for the catalysts is still high, which is not conducive to the expansion of production. Therefore, pure transition metal HEAs have become the focus of current research. In this regard, porous HEAs nanoparticles (FeCoNiCuMn-NPs) have been synthesized by solvothermal method [65], and used high-entropy metal-organic skeletons (FeCoNiCuMnZn-MOFs) as precursors of HEAs, and passed the precursors into different temperatures and atmospheres (Ar/H2) to thermally reduce them, and the resultant HEAs are in the form FCC structure. Due to the low boiling point of zinc, pores are formed during thermal reduction through evaporation from the higher temperature. The formation of pores allows greater exposure of active sites [66] and improves diffusion efficiency [67]. So, the porous structure increases the specific surface area of the catalyst [68]. By observing the X-ray diffractometer (XRD) (Fig. 4 a) and SEM (Fig. 4b) images of HEAs, the smaller surface particles of the samples after thermal reduction expose more nanoparticles, thus increasing the number of active sites [69]. OER test is carried out by electrochemical standard three-electrode system in alkaline environment, it can be found that the overpotential required for the HEAs-950 °C current density of 10 mA·cm-2 is only 197 mV (as shown in Fig. 4c), and the Tafel slope is as low as at 55 mV·dec‑1, which further verifies the excellent performance of HEAs catalyst. A NiCoFeZnMo high-entropy metal-organic framework (HE-MOF) for alkaline environment has been synthesized by the solvothermal method [70], which is a class of organic-inorganic hybrid materials, known as coordination polymers, often used as a precursor to synthesize the desired materials [71]. Flow chart of HE-MOF grown in situ on nickel foam (Fig. 4d), which has a unique porous structure that prevents the buildup of nanoparticles and prevents the decrease in porosity, allowing for more efficient electron and intermediate transport during the reaction. By observing the SEM (Fig. 4e) and TEM images (Figure NiCoFeZnMo high entropy metal-organic skeleton (HE-MOF) was synthesized by solvothermal method in alkaline environment.structure of HE-MOF promotes the contact between the active sites and the electrolyte ions, which can enhance the electrical conductivity and increase the rate of electron transfer, resulting in the increased efficiency of oxygen production. According to the high resolution transmission electron microscope (HR-TEM) image, this catalyst has a small lattice spacing (1.23 nm (Fig. 4g)) and a good degree of crystallization. The thickness of the two-dimensional high-entropy metal-organic skeleton is about 1.8 nm as shown in the atomic force microscopy (AFM, Fig. 4h) image, which can provide more active sites and shorter transfer paths, helping to increase the rate of the catalytic reaction and thus improve the catalytic performance. HE-MOFs usually contain at least five or more different metal elements, and the structure of high-entropy metal-organic skeletons is relatively complex caused by the introduction of multiple elements, this complexity can provide richer performance and functionality. The catalytic properties of the materials can be modulated by adjusting the ratios and types of different metal elements and the selection of organic ligands. Due to the multi-element composition of the high-entropy metal-organic skeleton, it usually exhibits better thermal stability at high temperatures, which provides the possibility for high-temperature catalytic applications as well. HEAs (NiFeCuCoW) catalysts for alkaline environment have been synthesized on iron sheets by the electrodeposition method [72], the catalyst formed by different current densities show the different surface morphology. As shown in Fig. 5 a, the surface morphology of the catalyst shows a cauliflower shape using SEM images under 100 mA·cm-2, and the calculated electrochemical active surface area (ECSA) value is 364.0 cm2, this structure has a relatively large specific surface area and a higher number of exposed active sites, which is conducive to the improvement of catalytic activity, and these nanodots are more flexible in surface modification and coordination ability [73], shortening the diffusion paths of ions/electrons, and alleviating the stress caused by the structural changes of the electrode materials during the charging and discharging process, thus obtaining excellent specific power [74], superior multiplicity performance and cycling stability. The surface morphology of this catalyst did not change significantly after a long time of operation (Fig. 5b), indicating the excellent stability. For the synthesis of HEAs by magnetron sputtering is also more common, such as the synthesis of self-supported thin film electrode HEAs (FeCoNiCrMn) on nickel foam (NF) by magnetron sputtering [75], which does not require a binder and thus avoids its inhibitory effect on the conductivity of the material. Moreover, the three-dimensional porous mesh structure of nickel ensures full contact with the electrolyte, which in turn allows the electrochemical active sites of the electrocatalytic materials grown on its surface to be exposed as fully as possible with a large specific surface area. After the synthesis of FeCoNiCrMn high-entropy thin films also use the cyclic voltammetry (CV) to reconstruct the surface structure of the HEAs, so that the morphology of the film surface presents a grass-like as in Fig. 5c. The grass-like material for high-entropy oxides or hydroxides, and the formation of this grass-like material is usually composed of better conductivity, the active sites are more abundant. The different sputtering times have an effect on the performance of the samples, with too short a sputtering time leading to incomplete adsorption on the nickel foam surface, and too long a sputtering time resulting in too much adsorbent being dislodged due to gravity. After 16 h of stability testing in an alkaline environment (Fig. 5d), the high-entropy alloy HEAs film on the surface of nickel foam is not damaged and own the good stability. High-energy ball milling is also a common method used to make HEAs, and it has been reported in the literature that nanoporous HEAs (NP-NiCuMnCoFe) used in alkaline environments are prepared by combining high-energy ball milling and dealloying methods [76], and the oxidizability of high-valence ions is usually higher when undergoing electrochemical water decomposition, which is more likely to react with oxygen and have a higher activity for the oxygen precipitation reaction, and the introduction of the Fe element into this catalyst makes it possible to produce a HEAs with the high oxidation rate. The introduction of Fe element increases the ratio of Ni3+ and Co3+, and the increase in the ratio of high valence state ions promotes the reaction. Through (Fig. 5e) SEM, it can be seen that the ligaments and pores on the surface of NP-HEA are relatively homogeneous, with an average size of about 2–5 nm, and such a structure is favorable for charge transfer and desorption of reaction products. In the calculation of the d-band center of the catalyst by density functional theory (DFT) in Fig. 5f, it shows that the presence of Ni, Co and Fe elements promotes both adsorption and desorption of reactants, confirming the abundance of active sites. Fig. 5g shows the OER reaction mechanism of Fe in this catalyst and (Fig. 5h) the calculated ∆G* of Fe shows that the metal atom Fe provides additional active sites for this reaction, which is greatly able to promote the OER performances with the HEA. The surface morphology of the catalyst is directly proportional to the activity of the catalyst, and the morphology is related to the number of active sites exposed to the catalyst. The cauliflower-like and grass-like morphologies mentioned above can expose more active sites to the catalyst, which can preferably contact with water molecules, and the specific surface area of the catalyst can be increased, thus obtaining higher catalytic performance. In the process of OER, the proportion of high valence metal ions affects the overall process of OER, and the high valence metal can be better bonded with O* and OH*, and the required energy can be reduced, thus promoting the process of OER. The synthesis of carbon-supported HEAs nanoparticles (NiCoFeCrMo-NPs) through the rapid Joule heating method is a commonly employed technique [77], a method an ultra-fast high-temperature synthesis of catalytic materials [78], allowing a rapid temperature rise and fall of the reactants, accelerates the rate of the reaction, can avoid the segregation of the alloying phases from each other. The synthesis step by step diagram is presented in Fig. 6 a, where graphene is used as a substrate and equal amount of metal chloride is doped on it, and sodium borohydride is used for reduction to synthesize the precursor, and finally fast Joule heating is used to synthesize the graphene-loaded HEA-NP. Zeta potential test is carried out after the synthesis of the precursor to find out whether graphene and the metal facets are successfully bonded or not, and the measured value (−25.4 mV) indicated the presence of electrostatic adsorption between them. After (Fig. 6b) XRD tests showed that this catalyst exhibits FCC structure. It can be observed by (Fig. 6c) TEM that the metal was uniformly distributed on graphene to form nanoparticles, and graphene as loading has a large specific surface area and good electrical conductivity, which can provide more reaction sites and fast electron transfer channels, thus improving the efficiency and activity of electrocatalytic reaction, and good chemical stability, which can be maintained under extreme environments, such as high temperature, high pressure, strong acid, strong base and so on. performance, enabling the electrocatalysts to exert better catalytic effects under these conditions. In order to develop a bifunctional catalyst for hydrogen and oxygen evolution reactions in an alkaline environment, a powder of HEAs (CoCrFeNiMo) has been developed [79], and the above mentioned metals are melted into alloy bar materials and gas atomization method is used to prepare HEAs powders, which is often used in the preparation of particles and powders [80], and it has been widely used in the field of metals and alloys in particular. The powdered HEAs has a relatively uniform composition distribution, and the formation of spherical nanostructures with a uniform degree of distribution can be clearly observed by (Fig. 6d) SEM images. The formation of a porous structure on the catalyst surface can be observed by HRTEM in Fig. 6e, which can increase in the surface area of the catalyst to expose more active sites and the interaction between the catalyst and the reactants. In the electrochemical performance tests performed on the catalysts, both HER and OER tests show good overpotentials and superior durability. The electrodeposition method also allows the synthesis of HEAs (NiFeCuCoCe) [81] by using nickel foam as a substrate to electrolyze seawater, in addition to the formation of various hydroxyl oxides (HEA-NCFCC/NF@EA) on the surface of the alloys using electrochemical self-reconstruction techniques, which increases the lifetime of the catalyst in seawater and promotes the adsorption and resolution of OH- on metals, obtaining the better durability of the catalysts. and resolution for more efficient O2 precipitation. Through (Fig. 6f) the electrochemical self-reconstruction, the particles on the catalyst surface are uniformly distributed and show a layered structure, and this structure could effectively prevent the entry of Cl- and improve the corrosion resistance. Catalyst performance is tested in different environments (Fig. 6g), the OER performance of HEA-NCFCC/NF@EA in different alkaline medium solutions, the best performance at 1 M KOH, the Tefal slope is lower, the EIS test of the catalysts is found to have a very small radius circle, which indicates a higher catalytic activity, a faster reaction interface, and even a higher efficiency of the catalytic reaction. The stability of the catalyst is tested (Fig. 6h), and the current of the catalyst did not decrease significantly after 100 h of work, indicating excellent stability. Loading a HEAs onto a carbon-based material makes the transfer electrons more efficiently, improving the efficiency of the catalytic reaction. Both carbon-based materials and spherical materials have large surface areas with large specific surface areas, providing more active sites for HEAs. However, different structures of catalysts are needed in different environments. The presence of Cl- in seawater will reduce the lifetime of catalysts, and then the layered materials can effectively prevent the entry of Cl-, which can ensure the stability of catalysts. During the study, it is found that rare earth HEAs is also applied in electrolytic water. The researchers have used critical acid polymerization and calcination reduction to synthesize HEAs (FeCoNiMoCe HEA/C) [82], which has excellent performance in both HER and OER and is a bi-functional catalyst with good performance. Fig. 7 a shows the specific reaction diagram. This experiment is through Ce coordination of non-precious metal HEAs. In the test, it can be found that the preparation of FCC structure, according to Bragg equation calculation, the addition of Ce can increase the lattice spacing, more conducive to adsorption and increase the reaction rate. When tested in 1 M KOH solution (Fig. 7b and 7c), it is found that when the current density is 10·mA cm-2, the overpotential is only 260 mV, which is lower than that of commercial RuO2 (300 mV), and the Tafel slope of FeCoNiMoCe HEA/C (63.4 mV·dec‑1) is lower than that of other comparison samples. In the measurement of ECSA, it is found that the ECSA of FeCoNiMoCe HEA/C is significantly higher than that of ternary and quaternary alloys (Fig. 7d), and the stability test results show the good stability. Carbon supported high entropy nano-alloy (PtCuSnWNb/C) electrocatalyst has been successfully prepared by polyol reduction technology, aiming at overcoming the challenge of insufficient stability of ethanol fuel cells in acidic media [83]. The catalytic performance of the nano-alloy is evaluated by CV. Before evaluating the ethanol oxidation reaction (EOR) performance, the ECSA of the catalyst in 0.1 M perchloric acid (HClO4) aqueous solution is firstly calculate (Fig. 7e), and the ECSA value of PtCuSnWNb/C is 68.94 m2·g-1. Then, the EOR activity of different catalysts is further compared by CV curve in the mixed aqueous solution of 0.1 M HClO4 and 0.5 M ethanol (C2H5OH) saturated with argon gas (Fig. 7f). Compared with Pt/C catalyst, the initial potential of PtCuSnWNb/C is shifted to the negative direction by about 200 mV, indicating that it has a faster kinetic reaction rate during EOR process. In addition, among the alloys composed of Pt, Cu, Sn, W and Nb, PtCuSnWNb/C exhibits the highest peak mass activity, reaching 1.76 A·mg-1. It is worth noting that the introduction of carbon carrier significantly improves the EOR mass activity of PtCuSnWNb, which highlights the key role of high specific surface area carbon materials in the high entropy alloy catalyst system. As shown in Fig. 7g, PtCuSnWNb/C also performs well in EOR specific activity, reaching 2.56 mA·cm-2, which is better than other comparison samples. Finally, the stability of PtCuSnWNb/C was evaluated by 4000 consecutive CV cycles under acidic conditions (0.1 M HClO4 aqueous solution). The data are recorded after 1000 cycles, which shows that the electrocatalyst has the excellent stability. HEAs consist of a variety of transition metal elements, which can be used to optimize the catalytic performance by adjusting the composition and structure of the alloys to modulate their surface properties, including surface adsorption properties and electronic structure. The alloy surface can also design with a diversity of atomic structures, thus providing abundant active sites, which helps to increase the catalyst activity and improve the catalytic efficiency. Moreover, the heterogeneous structure of HEAs can control the metal electronic d-band centers, thus controlling the electron distribution and transfer [84], affecting the formation and dissociation of intermediates in the reaction, and the complex electronic structure gives them an advantage in this regard. High entropy effects can cause atoms not to be arranged according to the traditional crystal structure, but to exist in a highly mixed and disordered manner. This high entropy effect may support more active sites, increasing the reactivity of the catalyst. Typically HEAs have good corrosion resistance, which is essential for catalyzing reactions over long periods of time. Their stable structure helps the catalyst to remain active in the reaction environment. By adjusting the composition and structure of the alloy, the catalytic properties of HEAs can be tuned to suit the requirements of different catalytic reactions. This tunability allows HEAs to be optimized for specific reactions. Moreover, HEAs exhibit high catalytic activity under milder reaction conditions, which is important for reducing energy consumption and improving catalytic efficiency. Non-precious metal elements are usually cheaper than precious metal elements, so the use of non-precious metals as catalysts can reduce the production cost, which is conducive to large-scale applications. Non-precious metal elements can form many different structures, such as nanoparticles, nanowires, nanotubes, etc. These different structures can be adapted to different reaction types and conditions, making the catalysts perform better. The influence of catalyst structure on catalysis is very great, and for transition metals, nanostructures can be formed by chemical dealloying [85], the precursor alloy can also be formed, then etched and dealloyed to obtain the required nanostructure, so that a higher specific surface area and active center can be obtained, which can provide more catalytic active sites, and reduce the occurrence of side reactions, so as to have higher catalytic activity. HEAs as catalysts have more complex and diverse structures, providing more possibilities to modulate the catalyst performance. Due to their multi-component and highly mixed nature, their structures and properties tend to be more complex, and this complexity makes the understanding and prediction of their behavior more difficult. During catalyst design and optimization, the effects of alloy components on catalytic performance need to be fully understood, which may require more sophisticated models and experimental tools. The preparation of HEAs usually requires special preparation techniques, and the preparation process may involve high-temperature and high-pressure conditions, which increases the difficulty and cost of preparation. In addition, the selection and proportions of elements in the alloys need to be carefully regulated to ensure that the alloys have the desired properties. Due to the complex structure of HEAs, it may be difficult to identify the active sites in them and understand their catalytic mechanism. This is a challenge for the rational design of catalysts and the precise optimization of their performance. New ideas are provided for designing and optimizing catalysts to perform well in various catalytic reactions. In order to achieve more precise control of HEAs catalysts, the in-depth studies are needed to understand the specific roles and interrelationships of these effects. 3.3 Preparation of high-entropy derivatives 3.3.1 High-entropy hydroxides (HEH) High-entropy hydroxide is a layered hydroxide structure with a high degree of disorder, consisting of a mixture of multiple elements in equal molar ratios. The energy distribution is more uniform and the material structure is more stable. A high-entropy oxygen/hydroxide (FeCoNiCrMo-HEA) thin film electrode with a dense nanosheet array structure was prepared by magnetron sputtering coating method [86], and pre-treatment is performed in NiCl2 solution with the preparation flow diagram as shown in Fig. 8 a. A high-entropy oxygen/hydroxide in the shape of a nanorod was formed, which was then electrochemically reconstituted and tested in an alkaline environment to form a dense nanosheet structure. The presence of high Mo states in the catalyst can attract electrons to oxidize other metal atoms and promote the reaction. HRTEM images show (Fig. 8b and 8c) that the surface of the catalyst is composed of crystalline and amorphous regions, forming an array structure. The inside of the red circle represents the crystalline region and the outside of the red circle represents the amorphous region. The lattice distance of the crystalline regions is 0.239 nm, which has the good crystallinity. This structure creates interfaces owing more defects, which can serve as fast channels for diffusion. And the abundant defects can form many unsaturated bonds, and these high oxidation state unsaturated bonds coordinate with oxygen to form bonds [87], which can promote the reaction. The contact angle between this catalyst and water can be observed in Fig. 8d, which is crucial for the process of OER; the smaller the contact angle is more hydrophilic and more likely to produce oxygen. Nanoflower-like high-entropy hydroxide (FeNiCrMnCoOOH/NF) is synthesized by solvothermal method on NF [88]. The above metal hydroxides have received much attention for having tunable three-dimensional electronic structures, the heterogeneous structures formed between different hydroxides, and the interactions between multiple elements, thus effectively regulating the electronic structure and promoting OER. As can be observed in the SEM image of Fig. 8e, the catalyst surface exhibits a nanoflower structure, and the large specific surface area provides more active sites, which contributes to the transfer between electrons and protons, and the electrical conductivity is improved. Tested in an alkaline environment, the linear sweep voltammetry (LSV) image of this catalyst is observed in Fig. 8f. Compared with several comparison samples, the OER performance of (FeNiCrMnCoOOH/NF) catalyst is the best, and the voltage is only 201 mV when the current density was 10 mA·cm-2. And the catalyst has a low kinetic resistance, and the interaction between electrons is very strong, and has a strong promotion effect on OER. Layered double hydroxide is a tunable catalyst and its structure can be adjusted according to different needs. Layered double hydroxide catalysts have abundant active centers, which can provide more catalytic active sites and thus improve the efficiency and selectivity of catalytic reactions. For the preparation of high entropy layered double hydroxides (HELDH) can be synthesized using precipitation and hydrothermal methods, as an example of the synthesized sample (MgCoNi)3(FeAl)-LDH [89]. XRD images (Fig. 8g) and fitting results show that the synthesized (MgCoNi)3(FeAl)-LDH is consistent with the structure of metal oxide nanoparticles and layered bimetallic hydroxide nanosheets (M3N-LDH). Tests in an alkaline environment show that (FeCoNi)3(FeCr)-LDH has a low overpotential of only 230 mV at a current density of 10 mA cm−2 (Fig. 8h), while the Tafel slope is measured to be 49.3 mV·dec‑1 (Fig. 8i), representing a significant advancement in the investigation of high-entropy materials. High entropy hydroxide can remain stable under extreme conditions such as high temperature and pressure, which can be used as electrode material in batteries, supercapacitors and other fields, effectively improving the efficiency and stability of catalytic reaction and resisting the erosion of various corrosive media, thus improving the service life of catalyst. Due to the minimal impact even in the high-temperature environments, high entropy hydroxide can enhance the longevity of the catalyst. 3.3.2 High-entropy oxides (HEOs) HEOs differ from conventional oxides, which are usually composed of one or two metallic elements. The crystal structure of HEOs is characterized by a high degree of mixing, in which a variety of elements are distributed in a homogeneous manner in the crystals, creating a high-entropy effect. Due to their special composition and structure, HEOs may exhibit some novel physical and chemical properties. The composition of HEOs, in comparison to conventional oxides, can be more easily regulated, thereby offering greater possibilities for controlling their properties. Through precise adjustments to the alloy's composition and structure, it becomes feasible to tailor the properties of high entropy oxide materials, leading to enhanced advancements in the field of electrochemistry. High performance nanoporous and high entropy spinel oxide (FeCoNiCrMn)3O4 (L-HEOs) electrocatalyst has been prepared by a simple combustion method at room temperature [90], and the unique cocktail effect possessed by high-entropy spinel oxides can effectively regulate the electrical conductivity and catalytic activity of the materials [91]. Fig. 9 a shows the mechanism of high activity of OER, which is quenched and disposed after combustion to stop grain growth, and catalysts with smaller grain size have higher catalytic activity and selectivity. Through (Fig. 9b) SEM, it can be clearly observed that there are many pores on the surface, exposing more over active sites and improving the reaction rate. In order to verify the morphology characteristics of L-HEOs, we have carried out the specific surface area test on L-HEOs, which shows that the specific surface area of L-HEOs is 118.193 m2·g-1. This data confirms that L-HEOs have a large specific surface area, which implies that L-HEOs are able to better contact with the electrolyte and expose more active sites, being consistent with the morphological features of L-HEOs Fig. 9b (SEM). Based on the data in Fig. 9c, the results show that for elements Cr and Mn, the reaction rate is mainly determined by the adsorption of OH-, which has a free energy of adsorption of 1.60 eV and 1.53 eV, respectively. For element Fe, the reaction rate is mainly determined by the formation of O2, which has a free energy of formation of 1.33 eV. For Ni and Co elements, the reaction rate is mainly determined by the formation of O*, and the free energies of O* formation are 0.92 eV and 1.45 eV, respectively. Finally, electrochemical tests in an alkaline environment shows that the stability of the catalyst is extremely excellent. Preparation of Spinel Structure Catalyst HEO (CoFeNiCrMn) for Use in an Alkaline Environments by Sol Flame Method [92] to synthesize the best performing catalysts by different elemental ratios, which is a simple, low-cost, and easy-to-control preparation process, which can be used to prepare a variety of different kinds of nanomaterials. The experimental activity is analyzed by calculating the O* and OH* binding energies at three different active sites (Cr, Co, and Fe), and the results are displayed in a two-dimensional volcano (O*-OH*, OH*) overpotential thermogram (Fig. 9d). In addition, Fig. 9e shows the distribution of the OER activity as a function of the overpotential, where the O* and OH* binding energies are both lower for Co, indicating that at the Co site, O* and OH* bind relatively easily, i.e., the site has a high catalytic activity for the oxygen reduction reaction. Cr has a higher O* binding energy and a lower OH* binding energy. This suggests that the binding of O* is relatively difficult at the Co site, while the binding to OH is relatively easy, implying that the activity of this site for oxygen reduction reaction is somewhat limited. both O* and OH* binding energies are higher for Fe. It can be analyzed from the figure that most of the active sites in the catalyst are from Co, with Cr and Fe being the next most active. This experiment shows that the performance of HEOs can be adjusted according to different elements and ratios, and more in-depth research is needed. Calcite-type HEOs have also attracted much attention, with lanthanide HEOs (La-HEO) as the inner core and NiFeOOH as the outer shell, co-precipitation and chemical deposition methods were used for the synthesis of core-shell La-HEO@NiFeOOH heterostructures [93]. The addition of NiFeOOH has little effect on the crystal structure of La-HEO, and the NiFeOOH modification resulted in the formation of an ultrathin nanosheet structure (Fig. 9f), which can promote efficient electron transfer and fast mass transfer [94] and shorten the reaction path. The uniform distribution of elements can be seen through Fig. g–n, with Fe, Ni and O elements distributed in the outer layer corresponding to the formed core-shell structure. The efficiency of this catalyst for OER is greatly improved. HEOs can have abundant components, and the dependence on a single element can be reduced through the adjustment of components, which provides a new way to customize and regulate the electrochemical behavior of electrode materials. HEOs can maintain a stable structure even under extreme conditions, which can inhibit the volume expansion of electrode materials and improve their cycling performance. The multi-element synergism and inherent complex surface of HEOs can provide near-continuous adsorption energy, which is ideal for multi-step cascade reactions. HEOs produce a large number of defects in the electrode materials, which are favorable for electron and ion migration. 3.3.3 High-entropy sulfides (HES) Sulfur doping can increase OER activity during the preparation of electrocatalysts [95], So it is also considered in the preparation of HEAs. The specific reason sulfur doping for improving the performance is that it can change the physical and chemical properties of the catalyst, including morphology, structure, electron distribution, etc., which can greatly optimize the electrochemical performance of the catalyst. The (FeCoNiMoAl)Sx nanoparticle catalyst working in an alkaline environment is prepared by heat injection [96]. Observation of the TEM images shows (Fig. 10 a) that the nanoparticles exhibit a spherical shape with high specific surface area and reactivity, which can improve the reaction rate and catalytic activity. The introduction of Mo elements significantly reduced the kinetic energy barrier for the OER, while the dissolution of Al atoms led to the formation of more pores, thus exposing more active sites and enhancing the performance of the catalysts (Fig. 10b). High entropy CoFeNiCuCr vulcanization nanosheets (HE-LMH-S) are prepared using high entropy layered metal hydroxide (HE-LMH) as precursor and mild hydrothermal vulcanization method [97]. The high roughness of the sample surface can be seen through SEM (Fig. 10c), and the greater the surface roughness, the greater the number and availability of active sites, which improves the efficiency of the catalytic reaction. As can be seen from the LSV images tested in 1 M KOH (Fig. 10d), it can be seen that HE-LMH-S has a lower initial potential, and the current density is also significantly increased compared with the precursor body. After testing Fig. 10e it can be seen that the high valence state of metal ions is improved, and the high valence state of metal ions will promote the generation of the reaction, enhance the adsorption of O, and reduce the overpotential [98]. Moreover, the metal's complexes are more stable. For sulfur doping in catalysts can further optimize the electronic structure, which reduces the energy barrier of OER [99]. Higher conductivity and lower charge transfer resistance can be realized [100]. Sulfur doping changes the electron density and conductivity of the catalyst. The electrocatalytic capacity of the catalyst for oxidation is greatly enhanced, because sulfur addition can regulate the electronic structure of the catalyst, making it easier to excite or transfer electrons. In OER, sulfur doping can optimize the oxygen adsorption and reaction kinetics on the catalyst surface. For example, sulfur doping can form the new catalytic sites and improve the adsorption and activation of oxygen, thereby increasing the reaction rate and activity of the catalyst. Sulfur doping affects the reaction path of OER and changes the stability of the intermediates, which allows for more efficient reaction steps and higher reaction selectivity, thereby improving the overall reaction efficiency. As for the presence of multiple metal elements in equal proportions in HEAs, the HES exhibit a highly uniform atomic distribution, unlike the phase separation phenomenon in conventional alloys. This unique structure gives HES a highly uniform microstructure and chemical composition, which can obtain better performance in catalytic reactions. HES have a polytropic eutectic structure, i.e., multiple crystal structures exist simultaneously. This structure makes HES have complex crystal structure and phase transition properties, which shows the better stability and activity in catalytic reactions. HES owing excellent electrochemical properties, can work stably under different electrochemical windows, and have good corrosion resistance and stability, thus showing better catalytic performance in electrochemical reactions. 3.3.4 High-entropy phosphides (HEP) HEP is widely used in electrochemistry as a derivative of HEAs. In order to facilitate the preparation of nitrogen-doped high entropy metal phosphide HEMP (FeCoNiMnCdP) for application in alkaline environment, we have developed a metal-organic gel (MOG) precursor route [101]. The presence of MOGs has a significant effect on the rate of atomic mobilization, whereas the difference in elemental distribution then improves the OER properties to some extent. The presence of carbon and nitrogen in the gel realizes both carbon encapsulation and nitrogen doping, and N doping in the carbon-based carrier can significantly improve the stability [102]. By TEM observation (Fig. 10f), it can be clearly seen that the phosphide nanoparticles are uniformly distributed on the surface of carbon, and the average size of these particles is measured to be 28.1 ± 15.8 nm. The synthesis of this catalyst provides an idea method for the application of phosphorus doping in HEAs. In order to study the application of HEP in alkaline environment, NF is used as a substrate to deposit FeCoNiMnCu metal atoms on it by hydrothermal method, which is then heated in a tube furnace to phosphide amorphous high-entropy phosphide/carbon (FeCoNiCuMnPx/C) with heterogeneous structure [103], and the shielding of carbon layer wrapped around the phosphide phase is conducive to the enhancement of the corrosion resistance and the electronic conductivity, and it can maintain the long-term stability [104]. The following figure shows the synthesis process of high-entropy phosphide/carbon (FeCoNiCuMnPx/C) on NF substrate (Fig. 10g), and this structure can expose more active sites and increase the reaction rate. The irregular mesoporous curved mesh structure is observed in FeCoNiMnCuPx particles through Fig. 10h, and the mesh electric level can be further improved for OER performance [105]. The surface structure of the catalyst did not change significantly after working for several hours, showing great stability. Phosphorus doping significantly improves the activity of oxygen and hydrogen precipitation reactions [106]. During anodic potential scanning, phosphides undergo in situ chemical transformations to oxides or hydroxides, which significantly enhances their catalytic activity [107]. Phosphorization of alloys is also thought of in the preparation of high entropy materials, where changes in crystal surface charge density and lattice distortions due to phosphorus doping [108] play an important role in HEAs to achieve an increase in the reaction rate of OER. The introduction of phosphorus element alters the electronic structure of HEAs and increases the reactive sites, thus enhancing the catalytic activity, which is beneficial for redox reactions such as oxygen precipitation reactions. Phosphorus doping may alter the surface properties of the HEAs, such as increasing the surface active sites or altering the surface adsorption capacity, which may affect the kinetics of the oxygen precipitation reaction. Meanwhile, it can alter the electron transport properties of the HEAs, contributing to more efficient participation in the electron transfer step of the oxygen precipitation reaction 3.4 Other multicomponent alloy catalysts There are other multicomponent alloys that can be used as electrocatalysts for oxygen evolution reactions, such as the preparation of ternary alloy (FeNiCo) catalysts. The synthesis step (Fig. 11 a) is carried out by alkaline etching, by which multistage molecular sieves (ZSM-5) with a hollow structure are obtained. Next, hollow porous carbon (HPC) has been prepared by chemical vapor deposition (CVD) method and template removal process [109]. The formation of hollow porous structure can significantly increase the specific surface area and contribute to the exposure of more active sites. After etching, a hollow porous structure is formed (Fig. 11b), in which the diameter of the hollow core is about 100 nm. the formation of the hollow structure provided more active surfaces, which extremely enhance the catalytic performance. In addition, it further improves the substance transport efficiency within the catalyst and reduced the diffusion path, which promotes the rapid diffusion of reactive substances to the catalytic active sites. By measuring LSV in an alkaline environment (Fig. 11c), it can be observed that HPC-FeCoNi has an overpotential of 219 mV at a current density of 10 mA cm-2. This value is lower than that of commercial RuO2 (350 mV), indicating that FeCoNi alloy nanoparticles on hollow porous carbon have excellent electrocatalytic properties. Fe-doped NiCo2O4 samples working in alkaline environment were synthesized by a two-step synthesis method. The nickel foam used as the carrier, is firstly reacted in the reaction kettle to obtain the required PH value, and then calcined in the air to make the crystals grow better. Finally, the Fe0.5Ni0.5Co2O4 catalyst is successfully prepared [110], meanwhile, the proportion of elements in this catalyst is the best. The nanowire structure can be clearly observed through SEM (Fig. 11d). Due to its highly structured characteristics, there are usually a large number of surface active sites on the nanowires, which can help to improve the activity and selectivity of the catalyst. Moreover, it is observed by TEM (Fig. 11e) that the nanowires are composed of smaller nanoparticles, the size of which was in the nanometer scale and had a size effect, making their electronic structure and surface properties being different from those of bulk phase materials, which makes the nanoparticle catalyst exhibit special catalytic properties. In the electrochemical test, it can be found that different Fe contents at the current density of 10 mA·cm-2 and the comparison diagram of Tafel slope (Fig. 11f), different synergistic effects will occur with different Fe doping proportions, and then different structures will be produced, which has a close relationship with the activity of the catalyst. The synergistic effect can enhance the catalytic activity. Due to the different atomic sizes and electronegativity of various elements, the complex local structures they form in the lattice provide rich active sites, thus enhancing the adsorption and conversion ability of the catalyst to the reaction substrate, and enhancing the activity of the catalyst. By combining monolithic high conductivity nickel iron foam (INF) collectors with molybdenum sulfide nanowire structures with highly active catalytic interfaces, the researchers successfully prepared Fe/Co/Ni-MoSx/INF catalysts by a simple hydrothermal method [111]. The results of SEM revealed a uniform distribution of Fe/Co/Ni-MoSx nanowires on the surface of the INF, forming an array-like structure (Fig. 12 a, b). In Fig. 12c, the linear sweep voltammetry (LSV) curve of Fe/Co/Ni-MoSx/INF is measured in an alkaline environment. Fe/Co/Ni-MoSx/INF integrated electrodes exhibit excellent REDOX reaction performance, and the generation of current densities of 10 mA·cm-2 and 100 mA·cm-2 required 214 mV and 263 mV over the potentials. This indicates that the prepared Fe/Co/Ni-MoSx/INF catalysts perform well in promoting redox reactions with high catalytic activity. The design of this combined structure not only provides a high conductivity substrate (INF collector), but also introduces a highly active molybdenum sulfide nanowire structure on its surface, which provides an effective way to enhance the electrocatalytic performance. Quaternary alloys are also widely used as electrocatalysts, and binder-free quaternary alloys (NiFeWMo) are constructed by electrodeposition process [112]. The advantages of binderless nanostructure of quaternary alloy (NiFeWMo) extremely promote the progress of OER, because binderless can make the active site be exposed, obtain higher catalytic activity and even the better electrical conductivity. After the electrodeposition treatment, the surface of these crossed wires is transformed and became rough and uneven (Fig. 12d). This surface change helps to promote the diffusion of electrolyte and exchange of intermediates while improving the conversion efficiency of electrons, thus enhancing the effective contact between the reactants and the active substance during the water electrolysis process. The high resolution transmission electron microscope (HR-SEM) images (Fig. 12d and 12e) show that the coatings on the Ni lattice formed a block structure after the electrodeposition process. By directly growing the nanostructures on the conducting substrate, it helps to provide abundant active sites and ensures a short diffusion path, thus enhancing the electrocatalytic performance. Such directly grown nanostructures also leave some gaps between the coatings, which may provide additional electroactive sites by acting as electrolyte reservoirs. Thus, this design strategy optimizes the performance of the electrocatalytic materials by tuning the surface morphology and structure to provide favorable conditions for efficient reactions during water electrolysis. When measuring electrochemistry in an alkaline environment, it is found that the Ni-Fe-W-Mo alloy only needs a low overpotential of 152 mV to reach 10 mA·cm-2, and the stability (Fig. 12f) is good. In order to improve the activity of the catalyst, one of the common preparation methods is etching. Etching can expose more active sites, thereby shortening the reaction path between ions and speeding up the reaction. The structure of the catalyst array and the roughness of the catalyst surface are two common characteristics, which has the important effects on the performance of the catalyst. The characteristics of the array structure enable the catalytic active sites to be uniformly distributed on the catalyst surface. In addition, this uniform distribution helps to improve the homogeneity of the reaction and the catalytic efficiency. When the active sites are evenly distributed, the reactive substances are more likely to interact with these sites, thus promoting the reaction. Moreover, rough surfaces can provide more adsorption sites. These additional adsorption sites can extremely increase the contact area between the reaction substance and the catalyst surface, thus enhancing the adsorption process. By providing more adsorption sites, the rough surface improves the initial step of the reaction, which in turn facilitates the REDOX reaction. Therefore, through structural design and surface engineering, the advantages of array structure and rough surface can be used simultaneously to improve the performance and efficiency of the catalyst. The etching method allows for precise control over the morphology, size, and crystal surface structure of the catalyst, thereby enabling control over its activity and selectivity. This level of precision enhances the catalyst's performance, making it better suited for specific reaction conditions and application scenarios. 4 Conclusion The HEAs is a material composed of multiple elements with a diverse range of surface sites and electronic structures, offering numerous possibilities for catalytic reactions. The synergistic effect of multiple elements further enhances the OER. The atoms of HEAs catalyst have similar radius and electron affinity, which can make the adsorption capacity of reactants more uniform, thus improving the whole reaction rate and selectivity. The lattice distortion-induced irregularities bring about more surface defects and reaction opportunities to the catalyst, thus enhancing its catalytic activity. Additionally, the HEAs exhibits excellent conductivity, ensuring efficient electron transport and providing strong support for electrocatalytic reactions. In order to improve the electron transport efficiency of HEAs, highly conductive elements can be selected as alloy components and crystal structures with high conductivity (such as FCC) can be designed. Nanostructures are prepared to increase the specific surface area and improve the electron transport efficiency. The introduction of pore structures increases the active site and improves electron and ion transport. Optimize the surface structure by coating or surface modification technology, reduce obstacles, and thus increase the electron transport rate. High temperature annealing can reduce lattice defects and impurities and increase electron mobility. The addition of electrical conductivity enhancers or the use of high-energy ball milling techniques can also improve the electrical conductivity and catalytic activity. In situ synthesis technology is used to control the structure and composition of the alloy in real time to optimize the electron transport performance. Real-time monitoring of electrochemical characterization and optimization of alloys. Theoretical calculation and simulation prediction are used to guide the experimental optimization. The chemical stability is also outstanding, allowing it to maintain its original structure and catalytic efficiency even in harsh environments, making it reliable for long-term operation. Due to its composition of various elements and unique crystal structure, HEAs often possess excellent corrosion resistance a critical property, when electrocatalysis is applied in challenging environments. Although HEAs has potential as an electrocatalyst, it still faces challenges. Its preparation requires high pressure, high temperature and inert gas environment, which increases the cost and energy consumption. At the same time, the structure-activity relationship of HEAs electrocatalysts is still unclear, and the complex composition and structure make it difficult to identify the active center, which is crucial for the design, manufacture, modification and improvement of catalytic performance. Therefore, it is necessary to explore a new synthesis path to more accurately control the composition, size and uniformity of HEAs, and strengthen the research on in-situ characterization techniques to deeply understand the structural evolution and mechanism of HEAs in electrocatalytic reactions, so as to guide catalyst design and optimization. Meanwhile, the regeneration and recovery technology of HEAs catalyst is studied to realize resource recycling and environmental protection. Despite the challenges, HEAs has the broad application prospects in the field of electrocatalysts and are expected to play a more important role in the field of energy conversion and storage in the future. coredata.dc:description: High entropy alloys (HEAs) are composed of five or more atomic components, forming a homogeneous solid solution with a highly disordered crystal structure. This unique structure can increase the number and diversity of surface active sites, which is conducive to improving the rate and selectivity of catalytic reactions. Additionally, it exhibits good catalytic activity, stability, and antioxidant properties. This paper detailedly discusses the preparation method, structural characteristics, and application in catalysis of HEAs catalysts for oxygen evolution reaction (OER). Different methods can control the composition and microstructure of the alloy, thereby affecting the catalytic performance. Through density functional theory (DFT) studies on HEAs, it is demonstrated that Gibbs free energy is reduced, further confirming the effect of HEAs on OER performance. The various techniques for preparing HEAs and their derivatives, as well as the incorporation of different elements, are summarized. These different methods and introductions can synthesize diverse catalyst structures with evaluated electrocatalytic performances. HEAs catalysts can utilize waste metals or recycled materials along with green synthesis methods, making them promising in terms of sustainability and environmental protection to promote sustainable development and application of catalytic technology.
